Liu Jing
Liu Jing of Pengcheng was traveling through Mount Jinhua in search of truth and the Dao. When he reached the mountainside, he noticed the scenery was extraordinary—the mountains and streams were lush and verdant. He saw towering gates and lofty pavilions soaring above the clouds. Upon entering, he found clear pools on either side, fine trees arranged in orderly rows, their trailing vines delicate, and their fruit resembling pears, their fragrance filling the air. Liu Jing looked around but saw no one. He plucked some of the fruit and tucked it into his sleeves, intending to eat it later. Suddenly, several fierce dogs bounded out, barking and snarling, ready to attack. Flustered and at a loss, Liu Jing looked around but found no stones to throw. He reached into his sleeves for the fruit he had picked and hurled it at the dogs. Once the fruit was gone, the dogs departed. When he turned back, the palaces and halls had disappeared, leaving only overgrown woods and thickets.

At the time, the monk Xiu was a close friend of Liu Jing and often spoke of this event.

Pengl Qiu

Pengl Qiu, styled Bojian, was a native of Beihai. During the Tai Shi era of the Jin dynasty, he entered the Jade Maiden Mountain west of Beiqiu to fell timber. Suddenly, he detected a strange fragrance and followed the scent with the wind. The mountain parted of its own accord, revealing towering palaces and sprawling halls, their terraces and pavilions grand and expansive. Qiu entered through the gate and peered inside, where he saw five jade trees. Advancing slightly, he beheld four immortal maidens playing *weiqi* in the hall. Upon seeing Qiu, they all rose in surprise and asked, “Master Peng, how have you come here?” Qiu replied, “I followed the fragrance.” With that, they resumed their game as before. A younger maiden ascended a tower, plucking her zither in jest and singing, *“Why does Yuanhui alone ascend the tower?”* Qiu stood by one of the trees, and feeling hungry, licked the dew that dripped from its leaves.

Presently, a woman arrived riding a crane and said, “Yuhua, why have you allowed this mortal here?” She added, “The Queen Mother—now known as Wang Fangping—is inspecting the chambers of the immortals. You must send him away at once.” Terrified, Qiu fled through the gate, and when he turned back, all had vanished. Upon returning home, he found it was already the Jianping era. The old villagers and his former dwelling had become ruins and graves. Thereafter, he wandered through famous mountains in search of the Dao and never returned.

Wang Kejiao

Wang Kejiao was a native of Kunshan in Suzhou. Originally a farmer, he had no knowledge of the Dao. At the age of several years, his eyes began emitting a five-colored light, which intensified at night, allowing him to see clearly even in pitch darkness. Some said to his kin, “This is an affliction—when the light fades, he will lose his sight.” His parents, in their ignorance, summoned a common physician to cauterize his eyes, and the light vanished.

In the eleventh month of the tenth year of the Xiantong era, Kejiao was returning home from the market when he saw a large barge on the river, adorned with gold and brocade, embellished with pearls and kingfisher feathers, and filled with music. Kejiao stood watching as the barge drew near the shore. A youth in azure robes beckoned him aboard, where he saw over ten figures in towering crowns and feathered robes, their garments patterned with clouds, mist, mountains, and rivers, each holding a musical instrument. One of them announced, “Uncle Wang the Third wishes to meet you, though we know not whence he comes.” Another remarked, “His immortal bones have been damaged by fire. He must not drink wine, and if he abstains from food for ten years, he may attain the Dao.” They gave him a chestnut, instructing him to eat it. Kejiao consumed half, keeping the other half in his hand.

The traveler led Jian into a dim chamber, where a desk, brushes, ink, and other writing implements were arranged. He handed Jian a scroll of yellow silk and over ten sheets of paper, saying, "Since you have an affinity for writing, copy these for me." Unfurling the scroll, Jian saw it was all in ancient seal script. Though he had never studied such characters, and indeed had never pursued formal learning, his heart sank at the difficulty. Yet the Daoist had already departed, leaving no room for refusal. Tentatively, he followed the text and found it surprisingly easy—he completed the task in half a day. The Daoist then offered him a cup of broth, saying, "This is the divine nectar of Jinhua, not to be lightly obtained. Whoever drinks it shall enjoy boundless longevity." Its taste was sweet and exquisite. The Daoist commended him, expressed his gratitude, and sent him off, adding, "When the world grows troubled, return to this Jinhua Grotto-Heaven of Lang." Stepping outside, Jian felt as if waking from a dream—three days had already passed.

chunks.original_text: 山之峭睑，号大兰羊额，才通乌径，攀绿一道，以绝他路。 图与三人相值同行，皆无见者。 是夕，宿晋之庐长迟明，图复还所居，与善友者高谭通夕昧爽问，图衣纸道衣，秉简长跪而化。 所蓄书册、衣物，一一条疏，封於其前，发缄视之，则颁遗旧亲交友，靡不周悉。 弟拘於儒礼，哭之恸，良久复苏，语曰：吾得道耳，非死也，何哀恸如此？ 为言讫，奄然复化。 是岁，渐有兵戈。 自此中原多垒，远近饥馑，率如其言矣。 图秉版跪化，弟云坐化，非儒家之事，伸其足而座之。 书之者痛其拘於俗，而不达於道也。 吴磻 昊磻者，别业在湖州卞山下。 其侧有堆阜，高三四丈，围数步，巨石歌斜，以盖其顶。 墦偶率人力，以长绳挽之，石忽倾侧。 其下有石穴，深而甚明。 使一人夫锤组而下，见穴中瓮十余行列，两壁下满，中有水如血色。 又有诸小器皿，若铜非铜，若金非金，皆有光耀，其锂镂精巧，若非人工。 洞穴渐深，惊惧而出。 取器之最小者，欲示於外。 及出穴，亦失所在，乃以石覆之。 其后有人於侧近林中得一铜瓮，可受六七斗，亦满中赤水，倾弃溪中，数日，溪水皆赤。 又有老母，拾得文石，光彩可骯。 偶坠火中，则异香之气闻於远近，知其非常，因收而宝之。 每投火中，异香亦如旧，寻竟亡去。 时有里人，得谶云卞山下有无价香、长生药，即老母文石之香，昊墦十瓮之水，符其谶矣。 王生 王生者，尝游湖州乌程，过金子山下。
chunks.translated_text:
The mountain's sheer cliffs, known as Great Orchid Ram's Brow, allowed passage only by a narrow bird-track, a single green path that cut off all other routes. Tu and the three Daoists met and walked together, unseen by anyone else. That evening, they lodged at Jin’s hut. At dawn’s first light, Tu returned to his own dwelling. There, he spoke through the night with his close friend Gao Tan until the dim glow of predawn. Then, clad in a paper Daoist robe and holding a bamboo slip, he knelt upright and transformed. All his books and belongings were meticulously inventoried and sealed before him; when opened, they were found to be distributed among old relatives and friends, with nothing overlooked.

His younger brother, constrained by Confucian rites, wept in grief until, after a long while, Tu revived. He said, "I have attained the Dao—this is not death. Why such sorrow?" Having spoken, he suddenly transformed again. That year, warfare indeed erupted. From then on, ramparts multiplied across the Central Plains, and famine spread far and near, all as the Daoists had foretold.

Tu’s transformation—kneeling with a tablet—along with his brother’s seated passing, were not Confucian customs; thus, his brother stretched out Tu’s legs and seated him properly. The chronicler lamented his brother’s confinement by worldly conventions and failure to grasp the Dao.

Wu Fan
Wu Fan’s secondary estate lay at the foot of Mount Bian in Huzhou. Beside it stood a mound, three or four *zhang* high and several *bu* in circumference, its summit crowned by a massive, slanting boulder. Wu Fan once led laborers to haul it with long ropes, and the stone suddenly tilted. Beneath it yawned a cavern, deep and luminous. A worker descended with a rope and saw rows of jars lining the cave—over ten in all—filling both walls, their interiors brimming with blood-red water. There were also many small vessels, neither bronze nor gold yet gleaming, their engravings so exquisite they seemed beyond human craft. As the cavern deepened, fear drove him out. He took the smallest vessel to show outside, but upon emerging, it vanished. The cave was then resealed with stone.

Later, someone found a bronze jar in a nearby grove, holding six or seven *dou* of the same crimson liquid. When poured into a stream, the water turned red for days. An old woman also discovered a patterned stone, lustrous and fine. When it accidentally fell into fire, an extraordinary fragrance wafted far and wide. Recognizing its rarity, she kept it as a treasure. Each time it was cast into fire, the same fragrance arose, though it eventually disappeared.

At the time, a local villager received a prophecy: "Beneath Mount Bian lies priceless incense and the elixir of immortality." This matched the old woman’s fragrant stone and Wu Fan’s ten jars of crimson water, fulfilling the prophecy.

Wang Sheng
Wang Sheng once traveled through Wucheng in Huzhou, passing beneath Mount Jinzi.

chunks.original_text: 遇石门大开，遂由其中。 居第栉比，闻井棋布，名花异木，迨非人世。 其居人，皆霞冠羽衣，风貌高古，若神仙焉。 王生周览胜异，颇有寓居之思，赋诗而复往寻之，金子山前，但见巨石峭崔，无复仙境矣。 金庭客 金庭客，咸通中，自刻溪金庭路由林岭问将抵明州，行二三十里#4，忽迷失旧路，忽忽#5而行，日已将暮，莫知栖息之所。 因遇一道士荷锄，明#6津焉。 道士曰：此去人家稍远，无寓宿之所，不嫌弊陋，宿於吾庐可也。 引及其家，则林径幽邃，山谷冲寂。 既憩应下，久之，烹野蔬药苗食之。 顷有扣其门者，童子报云：隐云观请来日斋。 洎晓，道士去，约童子曰：善祇奉客。 客因问隐云观置来几年，去此观近远。 答曰：自古有此观，去此五百里，常隐云中，世人不见，故以为名。 客惊曰：五百里甚远，尊师何时当还？ 答曰：尊师往来，亦顷刻耳。 俄而道士复归，欲留客久住，客方有乡关之念，恳辞而出，乃遣童子示其旧路。 行三二里，失向来所在。 及问，岁月已三四年矣。 寻即复往，再访踪，无追其处所矣。 #7 费玄真

The stone gate stood wide open, and so he entered through it. Rows of dwellings stood closely aligned, wells and pavilions dotted the landscape like a chessboard, while rare flowers and exotic trees flourished—scarcely resembling the mortal world. The inhabitants wore cloud-like crowns and feathered robes, their bearing lofty and ancient, as if they were immortals. Wang Sheng marveled at the wondrous sights, harboring thoughts of staying there. He composed a poem before departing, but upon returning to seek it again, before Mount Jinzi he saw only towering cliffs of sheer stone—no trace of the immortal realm remained.

**The Guest of Jinting**
During the Xiantong era, a traveler from Jinting set out from the Jinting Road near Kexi, passing through forests and ridges on his way to Mingzhou. After journeying twenty or thirty *li*, he suddenly lost the familiar path. Wandering in confusion as dusk approached, he found no place to rest. Then he encountered a Daoist carrying a hoe, who guided him. The Daoist said, "The nearest homes are far off, and there is no lodging to be had. If you do not mind humble accommodations, you may stay at my hut."

He led the traveler to his home, where the forest path was secluded and the mountain valley serene. After resting for some time, the Daoist cooked wild herbs and vegetable shoots for him to eat. Soon, someone knocked at the door, and a young attendant announced, "The Hidden Cloud Abbey requests your presence for tomorrow’s feast."

At dawn, the Daoist departed, instructing the attendant, "Take good care of our guest." The traveler then asked how long the Hidden Cloud Abbey had existed and how far it was from there. The attendant replied, "The abbey has existed since ancient times. It lies five hundred *li* away, perpetually concealed within clouds, unseen by the world—hence its name."

The traveler exclaimed in surprise, "Five hundred *li* is very far! When will your master return?" The attendant said, "My master’s comings and goings take but a moment." Soon after, the Daoist returned, urging the traveler to stay longer. But the traveler, longing for home, firmly declined and departed. The Daoist then sent the attendant to show him the old path.

After walking two or three *li*, the traveler found the place he had come from no longer recognizable. Upon inquiry, he learned that three or four years had passed. He immediately returned to search again, but the location could no longer be found.

chunks.original_text: 费玄真者，成都双流县兴唐观道士也。 大中末，有道士自称昊子，来止观中。 淹留岁余，养气绝粒，时亦饮酒。 其为志也，泛然自适，无所营为。 忽谓玄真曰：吾欲为师写真，可乎？ 玄真笑曰：夫欲写真，先须自写。 昊子如其言，引镜濡毫，自写其貌，下笔惟肖，顷刻而毕。 复自为赞，兼诗二章，留遗玄真。 为赞及诗，未尝抒思，赞曰：不材吴子，知命任真，志尚玄素，心乐清贫，涉历群山，偷然一身，学未明道，形惟保神，山水为家，形影为邻，布裘草带，鹿冠纱巾，饵松饮泉，经蜀过秦，大道杳冥，吾师何人，瞩思下土，思彼上宾，旷然无已，罔象惟亲。 诗曰：终日草堂问，清风常往还，耳无尘事扰，心有骯云闲，对酒惟思月，餐松不厌山，时时吟内景，自合驻童颜。 又曰：此生此物当生涯，白石青松便是家，对月外云如野鹿，时时买酒醉烟霞。 又云：寂尔孤游，修然独立，饮木兰之坠露，衣乌兽之落毛，不求利於人间，绝卖名於天下，此山居之道士也。 题罢，振衣理策而去，莫知所在焉。 白桩夫 白桩夫，字永年，湖南衡岳人也，少有高趣，习神仙之道，三元八节，以诣岳中诸观。 助焚修朝谒之礼，问玄经参真之义，颇为高尚所叹异。 至於负薪汲水，勤苦寻师，不以为替。
chunks.translated_text:
Fei Xuanzhen was a Daoist of Xingtang Abbey in Shuangliu County, Chengdu. In the final years of the Dazhong era, a Daoist calling himself Wuzi arrived and stayed at the abbey. He lingered for over a year, cultivating qi and abstaining from grain, though he occasionally drank wine. His aspirations were free and unrestrained, untroubled by worldly pursuits. One day, he suddenly said to Xuanzhen, "I wish to paint your portrait—may I?" Xuanzhen smiled and replied, "If you wish to paint a portrait, you must first paint yourself."

Wuzi followed his advice, holding a mirror and dipping his brush to capture his own likeness. His strokes were lifelike, and the portrait was completed in an instant. He then composed a eulogy and two poems, leaving them for Xuanzhen. Neither the eulogy nor the poems showed any sign of deliberation. The eulogy read:

*Wuzi, of no talent,
Knows fate and follows the true.
His aspirations lean toward the mysterious and plain,
His heart delights in purity and poverty.
He wanders through countless mountains,
A solitary figure.
His learning has not yet illuminated the Dao,
But his form preserves the spirit.
Mountains and rivers are his home,
His shadow his only companion.
Clad in hempen robes and a grass belt,
A deer-hide cap and gauze turban.
He eats pine nuts and drinks from springs,
Traversing Shu and passing through Qin.
The great Dao is profound and obscure—
Who is my teacher?
Gazing upon the earth below,
I long for the celestial guests above.
Boundless and untethered,
I am intimate only with the formless.*

The poems read:

*All day in the thatched hall I inquire,
The clear wind ever comes and goes.
My ears are free from worldly clamor,
My heart at ease with the vast clouds.
Facing wine, I think only of the moon,
Feasting on pine, I tire not of the mountains.
Often I chant the Inner Landscape,
Naturally preserving a youthful face.*

*This life, these things—my livelihood,
White stones and green pines are my home.
Facing the moon, I see clouds like wild deer,
From time to time, I buy wine to intoxicate with mist and rosy clouds.*

He also wrote:

*Silent and solitary in my wanderings,
I stand alone in stillness.
I drink the dew that falls from magnolias,
Clothe myself in the shed fur of beasts.
I seek no profit in the human world,
Nor sell my name beneath the heavens.
Such is the Daoist who dwells in the mountains.*

Having inscribed these words, he adjusted his robes, gathered his staff, and departed—no one knew where he went.

**Bai Zhuangfu**
Bai Zhuangfu, styled Yongnian, was a native of Mount Heng in Hunan. From youth, he harbored lofty aspirations and studied the Way of immortals. On the Three Primes and Eight Festivals, he would visit the various abbeys of the mountain, assisting in the rituals of incense-burning and morning audiences, and inquiring into the profound classics and the mysteries of the true. His conduct was greatly admired by those of refined sensibilities. Even in tasks like gathering firewood and drawing water, he diligently sought instruction from masters, never considering it beneath him.

chunks.original_text: 因得丹书，飞步檄邪之术，修之二十年，由是济俗救民，惩妖松疾，赖其力者众矣。 巢寇犯阙，大驾西巡，海内干戈，纪纲凌素，酋豪犷暴者，所在自树置，不遵法度，师必约正道以戒之，从教者多矣。 时境内有豪帅，亡其姓名，尝为其子娶妇，吉日之前，一晨，忽有一少年，骑从十余辈，不知所从来，径造其厅事。 箕踞诟之曰：我先欲娉某氏女，汝何为夺之？ 众虽惊骇，莫敢酬对。 因使其徒，取熏绛羔鸦青钱束帛备物之数，以还之，而欲迫其女。 众疑其鬼物也，豪帅无以拒之，选迅足者走百余里，召师请明。 师将至，年少初无惧色，良久自谓曰：白尊师果来矣。 乃汶然流涕，跳跃上屋，号呼数声而灭。 所致之物皆在，师散之以遗贫病者。 师显以逆顺之理谕豪帅，豪帅知非，乃散释堡聚，松解兵卫，复为编民。 廉使州将嘉其事，湘衡问贤不肖者，皆美师之德，仰师之教焉。 一日，有樵人扣户，曰：西峰岩中有仙人会话，师可造之。 师疑其山木之妖也，熟睨其目睛，以辩邪正。 方摄衣将行，樵者曰：师功行已着，系籍仙简，何邪之敢？ 干然毫厘之差，勿为恨也。 言毕由他径去，师策杖寻之，至即暝矣。 但见崖壁有光，因熟视之，有诗焉，翰墨犹湿，其词曰：清秋无所事，乘雾出遥天，凭仗樵人语，相期白永年。 读讫即空壁无字，光亦止矣。 李颜 黔南节度李颜在镇之日，管内有安居山，巨崖临水，高数百尺，上有灵洞，乡里不知其名，常有神仙居之。 欲瞻礼者，乘舟其下，扣舷久之，即有云气异香之应。 乡人上陈李公，命道士泛巨舟，备斋醮虔洁，有真仙数十人，累累而集於崖顶，以观听法事者，三四日尚见。 至今若祈请者，往往见之也。 李班 李班者，符秦时人，颇好道术，常於卫国县西南游川穴山。 其山冬夏常出水，望之如练，时有瓜叶流出。 班入穴寻之，可行三百余步，廓然有明，中有官宇床榻经书几案，有二叉鬓发皓白，对坐床上。 班前拜之，顾曰：卿可还无宜久驻。 遂辞，出至穴口，有瓜数枚，欲取食之，已化为石。 寻故道还家，家人云，班去来已四十年矣。 裴沉从伯#8 裴沉，仕为同州司马。 云其再从伯自洛往郑州。 日晚，道左闻人呻吟，下马披蒿莱寻之，见一病鹤，垂翼倪味，翅上疮坏无毛，异其有声，恻然哀之。 忽有白衣老人，曳杖而至，谓曰：郎君年少，岂解哀此鹤耶？ 若得人血一涂，必能飞矣。 裴颇知道，性甚高逸，遽曰：某请刺此臂，血不难。 老人曰：君此志甚佳，然须三世人#9，是#1０唐已数百岁，隐之谒焉，．留宿及夜。 当呼其女曰：可将下弦月子来。 其女帖月於壁上，如片纸耳。 唐起祝之曰：今夕有客，可赐光明。 言讫，一室之内，朗然若张烛矣。 见《壶史》。 卢山人
chunks.translated_text:
Having obtained the alchemical scriptures, he mastered the arts of pacing the void and dispelling malevolence. After twenty years of cultivation, he thereby aided the common folk and saved the people, punishing demonic foxes and curing illnesses—many relied on his power. When the rebel bandits besieged the capital and the imperial cortege fled west, the realm was plunged into chaos, its order unraveling. Warlords and violent chieftains arose everywhere, defying law and discipline. The Master invariably admonished them with the principles of right and wrong, and many heeded his teachings.

At that time, there was a powerful warlord in the region—his name now lost—who once arranged a marriage for his son. On the morning before the wedding day, a youth suddenly appeared, accompanied by over ten riders, their origin unknown. He strode directly into the hall, sat with legs splayed, and berated the warlord: *"I had first sought to betroth the daughter of such-and-such a family—why have you stolen her?"* Though the household was alarmed, none dared respond. The youth then ordered his followers to retrieve the betrothal gifts—bundles of deep-red lambskin, black silk coins, and bolts of fine cloth—and return them, demanding the bride be handed over. Suspecting him to be a demonic entity, the warlord had no means to resist. He dispatched a swift runner over a hundred *li* to summon the Master and seek his aid.

As the Master approached, the youth showed no fear. After a long while, he suddenly muttered to himself: *"The Venerable Master Bai has indeed come."* Then, weeping bitterly, he leapt onto the roof, let out several wails, and vanished. The returned betrothal gifts remained, and the Master distributed them to the poor and ailing. He expounded the principles of retribution and moral order to the warlord, who, recognizing his wrongdoing, disbanded his fortifications, relaxed his military defenses, and returned to the register of common folk. The provincial governor and prefects praised his conduct, and throughout the regions of Hunan and Hengyang, whether in matters of worth or unworthiness, all extolled the Master’s virtue and revered his teachings.

One day, a woodcutter knocked at his door and said: *"On the western peak, immortals are gathered in conversation—you should go to them."* The Master suspected the woodcutter might be a mountain spirit in disguise. He fixed his gaze upon the man’s eyes to discern truth from falsehood. Just as he gathered his robes to depart, the woodcutter said: *"Your merit and conduct are already recorded in the registers of immortality—what demon would dare deceive you? Yet even the slightest misstep may bring regret."* With that, he took another path and left. The Master followed with his staff, but by the time he arrived, dusk had fallen. He saw only a radiant glow upon the cliff face. Peering closely, he found a poem there, its ink still fresh:

*On a clear autumn day, with nothing to do,*
*I ride the mist to the distant sky.*
*Relying on the woodcutter’s words,*
*I await Bai Yongnian’s arrival.*

As soon as he finished reading, the characters vanished from the blank wall, and the light faded. The woodcutter was nowhere to be seen.

**Li Yan**
During his tenure as military governor of Qiannan, Li Yan governed a region where Anju Mountain stood—a towering cliff hundreds of feet high, overlooking a river, with a sacred cave at its summit. The locals did not know its name but believed immortals dwelled there. Those who sought to pay homage would sail beneath it and strike the side of their boat, whereupon clouds and fragrant vapors would arise in response. The villagers reported this to Lord Li, who ordered Daoist priests to embark in a great vessel, preparing pure vegetarian offerings and solemn rites. Dozens of true immortals then descended in succession upon the cliff’s peak to observe the ceremony. For three or four days, they remained visible. Even now, those who make supplications there often catch glimpses of them.

**Li Ban**
Li Ban was a man of the Fu Qin dynasty, fond of Daoist arts. He often wandered the caves of Youchuan Mountain southwest of Weiguo County. The mountain’s streams flowed year-round, appearing like white silk from a distance, and gourd leaves would sometimes drift upon the water. Li Ban entered the cave and followed it for over three hundred paces until he emerged into a vast, luminous space. Within stood halls, beds, scriptures, and tables. Two white-haired elders with forked topknots sat facing each other on a dais. Li Ban bowed before them, and one turned to him, saying: *"You should return—it is not fitting to linger."* He took his leave and, upon reaching the cave’s mouth, found several gourds. As he reached to eat one, it turned to stone. Following the same path home, his family told him: *"You have been gone forty years."*

**Pei Chen**
Pei Chen served as the Prefectural Administrator of Tongzhou. His second cousin once traveled from Luoyang to Zhengzhou. As evening fell, he heard groans from the roadside. Dismounting, he pushed through the undergrowth and found an ailing crane—its wings drooping, its feathers molting from festering sores. Moved by its cries, he pitied it. Suddenly, an old man in white, leaning on a staff, appeared and said: *"Young sir, how could you understand compassion for this crane? If you were to apply human blood to its wounds, it would surely fly again."* Pei, well-versed in Daoist teachings and of a lofty disposition, immediately replied: *"I will cut my arm—blood is no difficulty."* The old man said: *"Your resolve is admirable, but it must be the blood of one who has lived three lifetimes..."*

**Tang**
...already several hundred years old, he concealed himself and received visitors. He stayed the night, and at midnight, called to his daughter: *"Bring the crescent moon child."* She affixed the moon to the wall—no larger than a sheet of paper. Tang rose and prayed: *"Tonight we have a guest—grant us light."* As soon as he spoke, the room brightened as if candles had been lit. *(Recorded in *The Kettle History*)*

**Master Lu of the Mountain**

His conduct was greatly admired by those of refined sensibilities. Even in tasks like gathering firewood and drawing water, he diligently sought instruction from masters, never considering it beneath him.

**Master Lu of the Mountain**

During the Baoli era, Master Lu was often seen at the southern grass market of Baibo, trading in quicklime. For years, those who encountered him witnessed many strange occurrences. The merchant Zhao Yuanging, a man fond of unusual affairs, sought to travel with him. He frequently purchased Lu’s goods, offered melons and tea, and inquired about his profits. Lu, sensing his intent, said: *"I see your purpose lies not in trade—what do you seek?"* Zhao replied: *"I have heard, venerable one, that you conceal your form and hide your virtue, seeing through the past like a tortoise or a diviner. I humbly beg a single word of guidance."*

Lu smiled and said: *"Today shall serve as proof. At noon, the master of this house will face an extraordinary calamity. Someone will intrude with ill intent—warn his wife and children not to respond lightly. Let them shut the door and retreat to the waterside to avoid it. The cost will be no more than three strings and four hundred coins, and no great harm will come. Otherwise, the disaster will be severe. You may go and tell him this directly."*

At the time, Zhao was staying at Zhang’s home. He relayed Lu’s words to Zhang, who, having long known of Lu’s divine nature, promptly shut his door and waited. As noon approached, a pastry-maker arrived, carrying a sack as Lu had described. He knocked, demanding to be let in, and grew furious when no one answered, kicking the door and hurling abuse. A crowd gathered as Zhang and his family slipped out the back gate to avoid him. By noon, the man departed. A few steps later, he suddenly collapsed and died.

After some time, the man’s wife arrived, wailing and demanding the authorities be summoned. The official, unable to settle the matter fairly, questioned the onlookers, who all testified to Zhang’s closed-door retreat. The official declared: *"Zhang bears no guilt. Let him prepare a seat and burial goods instead."* The wife, relieved, agreed, and the cost came to exactly three strings and four hundred coins.

From then on, people flocked to Lu like a marketplace. Unable to bear the attention, he eventually departed.

chunks.original_text: 尝谓赵曰：世问刺客，隐形者不少，逐者得隐形者亦不少，逐者二十年可易形名，又二十年名列地仙，所言率多奇怪。 赵云卢生状貌，老少不常，亦不见其饮食。 又尝於复州市，与数人行，遇六七人，盛服带酒，卢叱之曰：汝辈所焉，不俊性命。 无几，六七人罗拜尘＊中，曰：不敢，不敢。 同行者讶之，卢曰：此尽是劫江贼也。 其异 如此，盖得道隐仙之流也。 权同休友人 权同休。 元和中举进一年#11，先游海湖间#12，遇病贫窘，有村夫佣雇，已一年矣。 秀才疾中，思甘豆汤，令其市甘草。 雇者但具汤火，竟不为市，疑其息惰，而未暇诘之。 忽见折小树枝，盈握搓之，近火已成甘草。 又取厅沙授之，为豆汤，诚与真无异，秀才大异之。 疾稍愈，．谓雇者曰：余贫疾多时，既愈，将他适，欲市少酒肉，会村中父老，丐少路粮无以办之。 雇者遂乃斫一枯桑树，成数筐扎，聚於盘上，以水洒之，悉成牛肉。 ＂汲水数饼为酒，会村中父老，皆至醉饱。 获束缣三十婚，秀才方暂谢雇者曰：某骄遇道者，过亦甚矣，今请为仆役，以师事焉。 雇者曰：余少有失，请为佣贱#13，合役於秀才，自有限日，勿请变常，庶卒某事。 秀才虽诺之，每所呼指，常蹙蹙不安。 雇者乃辞去，因为说修短穷达之数，且言万物无不可化者，唯淤泥中朱筋及发颓，药力不能化。 因去，不知所之。 神仙感遇传卷之二竟 #1『一』，《云笈七签》作『下』 #2『今』，《云笈七签》作『令』 #3『旦』，《云笈七签》作『早』。 #4此句《霎岌七签》作『三二十里』。 #5此句《云岌七笔》作『匆匆而行』。 #6此句《云笈七签》作『问津焉』。 #7此句《云笈七签》作『再访其综，无能知其处所矣』。 #8《云笈七签》作『裴沈』。 #9按《云笈七签》，此处有一段文字遣漏，『君此志甚佳，然须三世人，是其血方可中用，郎君前生非人，唯洛中胡芦生三世人矣，郎君此行非有急切，岂能却至洛，为求胡芦生耶？ 裴沈然而返洛中，访胡芦生，裴沉具陈其事，拜而析之。 生无难色，取一石合子，大加两指，以针刺臂，济如乳下，满合以授裴曰：无多言也。 及鹤处，老人喜曰：固是信士。 乃以血尽涂鹤疮上，言与之结缘。 既而谓裴曰：我所居去此不远，可少留也。 裴觉非常人，以得，吾与之友，出入游处，君自不知，今有一信，托君达之。 因裹一朴物，大如羹盎，戒无窃开。 共视鹤疮并已生毛矣。 又谓裴曰：君向饮浆，当哭九族，但戒酒色耳。 裴还洛中，将窃开其朴，四角各有赤蛇出头，乃止。 其叔开之，有物如乾大麦饭，因食之，入王屋山，不知所终。 裴寿到九十岁也』。 #10『然须三世人」以下至末尾一段文字，《云笈七签》无。 #11此句《云笈七签》作『元和中举进士下第』。 #12此句《云笈七签》作『游江湖问』。 #13『佣贱』，《云笈七签》作『凡贱」。 神仙感遇传卷之三 广成先生杜光庭集
chunks.translated_text:
Once, he said to Zhao: "In the world, there are no few assassins who can conceal their forms, nor are there few pursuers who can track those who hide. After twenty years of pursuit, one may change name and appearance, and after another twenty, one’s name may be listed among the earthly immortals. Such tales are often strange indeed."

Zhao remarked that Lu’s appearance shifted between old and young, and that he was never seen eating or drinking. He also recalled an incident in the market of Fuzhou, where Lu walked with several companions and encountered six or seven men dressed in fine robes, reeking of wine. Lu rebuked them, saying: "Where are you lot bound? Do you not value your lives?" Soon after, the six or seven men prostrated themselves in the dust, crying: "We dare not, we dare not." The companions were astonished, but Lu explained: "These are all river bandits." Such were his marvels—clearly one of the Dao-concealed immortals.

**Quan Tongxiu, a friend of Quan Tongxiu:**
During the Yuanhe era, he sat for the imperial examinations but failed. The following year, he traveled among the lakes and seas, where he fell ill and into poverty. A villager hired him as a laborer, and he had already served for a year. While still unwell, the scholar craved sweet bean soup and sent the laborer to buy licorice. The laborer prepared the fire and water but never purchased the herb. Suspecting laziness, the scholar did not press the matter. Suddenly, he saw the laborer break off a small tree branch, rub it in his hands, and hold it near the fire—whereupon it turned into licorice. The laborer then took some sand from the hall, shaped it into beans, and made soup that tasted no different from the real thing. The scholar was astounded.

When his illness had somewhat abated, he said to the laborer: "I have been poor and ill for a long time. Now that I am recovering, I intend to travel elsewhere. I wish to buy some wine and meat to gather the village elders, but I lack the means for provisions." The laborer then chopped down a withered mulberry tree, fashioned several baskets of kindling, piled them on a tray, and sprinkled them with water—whereupon they turned into beef. He drew water and transformed it into wine, and when the village elders arrived, all drank and ate their fill. The scholar received thirty bolts of silk as gifts.

He then addressed the laborer: "I have been arrogant in my encounter with a Daoist master—my error is grave. Henceforth, I beg to serve you as a disciple." The laborer replied: "In my youth, I made mistakes and became a lowly hireling. My service to you has its term; do not ask me to alter our usual ways, lest I fail in my task." Though the scholar agreed, he often hesitated, uneasy with the laborer’s commands. The laborer then took his leave, discoursing on the cycles of life and fortune, and adding that all things in the world could be transformed—except for the red veins in stagnant mud and fallen hair, which no medicine could alter. After speaking, he departed, and his whereabouts became unknown.

*Collected Works of Master Guangcheng, Du Guangting*
*Records of Divine Immortals’ Encounters, Scroll Two (concluded)*

chunks.original_text: 御史姚生 御史姚生，失其名。 郑州刺史郑权叔云：姚罢官，居于蒲之左邑，有子一人，外甥二人，各一姓，年皆及壮，而顽驽不肖。 姚之子稍长於二甥，姚怪其不学，日以诲责而息游不恢。 遂於条山之阳，结茅以居之，兼绝外事，得专艺学。 林壑重深，嚣尘不到。 将遣之日，姚戒之曰：每时季试汝之所能学，有不进，必复挞及汝，汝各宜勉焉。 及到山中，二子曾不开卷，而但朴断涂坚为务。 居数月，其长谓二人曰：试期至矣，汝曹都不省书，吾为汝惧。 二子曾不介意，其长学读甚勤。 忽一夕，半夜临烛托几，披书之际，觉所衣裘后倨，为物所牵，襟领渐下，亦不知异。 徐引而袭焉，俄顷复尔，如是数四。 遂回视之，见一小纯，藉裘而伏，色甚洁白，光润如玉，因以压书界方击之，纯声骇而走。 遽呼二子，秉烛索于堂中，牖户甚密，周视无陈，而莫知纯所往。 明日，有苍头骑扣门，梧策而入。 谓三人曰：夫人问讯，昨夜婴兄无知，误入君衣倨，殊以为暂。 然君击之过伤，今则平矣，君勿为虑。 三人俱逊词谢之，相视莫测其故。 少顷，向来骑僮复至，兼抱持所伤之儿，并乳褓数人，衣懦皆绮执，制造精丽，非寻常所见。 复传夫人语云：小兄无恙，故以相示。 逼而观之，自眉至鼻端，如丹镂焉，则界方所击之迹也。 三子愈恐，使者及乳褓皆甘言慰安之，又云。 少顷，夫人自来，言讫而去。 三子悉欲潜去，避之惶惑。

The Imperial Censor Yao

The Imperial Censor Yao—his given name is lost. Zheng Quanshu, Prefect of Zhengzhou, recounts: After Yao was dismissed from office, he resided in Zuoyi County of Pu. He had one son and two nephews, each of a different surname, all grown yet stubborn and unworthy. Yao’s son was slightly older than his two nephews. Yao, vexed by his son’s refusal to study, daily admonished and reproached him, yet the boy remained idle and undisciplined. Thereupon, Yao built a thatched hut on the southern slope of Mount Tiao, where he secluded his son, cutting off all external affairs so that he might devote himself wholly to learning. The forests and ravines were deep and layered, untouched by the clamor of the world.

On the day of his son’s departure, Yao warned him: “At each seasonal examination, I shall test your progress. If you fail to improve, I will surely flog you. You must all apply yourselves diligently.” Yet upon arriving in the mountains, the two nephews never once opened a book, busying themselves instead with chopping wood and breaking stones. After several months, the eldest said to them: “The examination period draws near. You have not studied at all—I fear for you.” The two paid no heed, while the eldest studied with great diligence.

One night, as he sat reading by candlelight at his desk, he felt his fur robe tugged from behind. The collar gradually slipped down, yet he thought nothing of it. He adjusted it, but soon it happened again—several times in succession. Turning to look, he saw a small creature crouched upon his robe, its fur pure white and lustrous as jade. He struck it with his ruler, and the creature shrieked and fled. He called to his two companions, and together they searched the hall with candles, but the doors and windows were tightly sealed, and no trace of the creature could be found.

The next day, a gray-haired servant arrived on horseback, knocking at the gate. He entered with a staff and addressed the three: “The Lady sends her regards. Last night, her youngest son, in his ignorance, mistakenly crept into your robe. She apologizes for the disturbance. However, your blow injured him severely. He has now recovered—do not worry.” The three bowed in apology, exchanging glances, unable to fathom the matter.

Shortly after, the same servant returned, cradling the injured child along with several nursemaids and infants, all clad in fine silk garments of exquisite craftsmanship, unlike anything seen before. He conveyed the Lady’s words: “My son is unharmed, and I bring him to show you.” Upon closer inspection, a red mark like carved cinnabar stretched from his brow to the bridge of his nose—the imprint of the ruler’s strike. The three grew even more alarmed. The servant and nursemaids spoke soothingly to reassure them, adding that the Lady herself would arrive shortly. As soon as she departed, the three resolved to flee in terror and confusion.

chunks.original_text: 未庾，有苍头及紫衣宫监数十人，奔波而至，前施屏喔捆席炳焕，香气殊异。 旋见一油襞车，青牛丹毂，其疾如风，宝马数百，前后导从。 及门，下车，则夫人也。 三人趋出再拜。 夫人微笑曰：不意小儿至此，君昨所伤，亦不至甚恐，为君忧，故来相慰耳。 夫人年可三十许，风姿闲整，俯仰如神，亦不知何人也。 问三子曰：有家室未？ 三子皆以未对。 夫人曰：吾有三女，殊姿淑德，可以配三君子。 三子拜谢，夫人因留不去，为三子各创一院，指顾之间，画堂延阁，造云而具。 翌日，有辎饼至焉，宾从璨丽，逾於戚里。 车服炫晃，流光照地，香满山谷。 三女自车而下，皆年十七八，夫人引三女升堂，又延三子就座，酒肴珍备，果实丰衍，非常世所有，多未之识。 三子殊不自意，夫人指三女曰：各以配君子。 避席拜谢，复有送女数十人，若神仙焉。 是夕合晋，夫人谓三子曰：人之所重者，生也，。 所欲者，贵也，但百日不泄於人，令君长生度世，位极人臣。 三子复谢，但以愚昧抒格为忧，夫人曰：君勿忧，夫人乃动地上主者，令召孔宣父。 须曳宣父具冠剑而至，夫人端立微劳问之，谓曰：吾三婿欲学，君其导之。 宣父及命三子，指六籍篇目以示之，莫不了然解悟，大义悉通，咸若素习。 既而宣父谢去。 夫人又命周尚父，示以玄女兵符、玉璜秘诀，三子又得之无遗。 复坐，举言则皆文乐公主遣上玺，书言勉之，国命暂屈高标。 至京，亲贵候，谒寒温之外，不交一言，授太子宾客，封国公，及还山，动翰林学士，赋诗送之。 荆州韶石 荆州利水问有二石，若门，名日韶石。 晋永和中，有二飞仙，衣冠若雪，各憩一石之上，旬日方去，居人咸共见之也。 曹桥潘尊师 杭州曹桥福业观，有潘尊师者，其家赡足，虚襟大#1度，延接宾客，功行#2济人。 一旦，有少年，容状疏俊，异於 常人，诣观告潘曰：其远聆尊师德义，拯人急难，甚欲求托师院后竹径中茅#3斋内，寄止两月，以避息难，可乎？ 或垂见许，勿以负累为忧，勿以食撰为虑，只请酒二斗，可支六十日矣。 潘虽不测其来，闻欲逃难，欣然许之。 少年遂匿於茅斋中，亦无人追访之，亦不饮不食。 六十日既满，再拜致谢焉。 从容问潘曰：尊师曾佩授符录乎？ 潘云：所受已及洞玄中盟矣，但未敢参进上法耳。 少年曰：师之所受，品位已高，然某曾受正一九州社令录一阶，以冒奉传，以申报答耳。 即焚香於天尊前，传社令名字，及灵官将吏。 随所呼召，兵士骑乘，应时皆至。 既毕，令之曰：传授之后，随逐尊师营卫，召命与今无异。 由是兵士方隐。 又谓潘曰：可於中堂垒床为坛，设案几，焚香恭坐，九州内外吉凶之事，靡不知也。 但勿以荤血为犯，苟或违之，冥必有谴。 若精洁守慎，可致长生神仙矣。 言讫隐去，不知所之。
chunks.translated_text:
Before long, a group of gray-haired servants and dozens of purple-robed palace attendants arrived in haste, bearing before them screens, canopies, and woven mats—all resplendent and gleaming—while an extraordinary fragrance filled the air. Soon after, a lacquered carriage drawn by a black ox with vermilion wheels approached like the wind, escorted by hundreds of fine horses. Upon reaching the gate, the occupant alighted—it was the Lady.

The three men hurried out to bow twice in greeting. The Lady smiled faintly and said, “I did not expect my son to trouble you so. The injury you inflicted yesterday was no cause for great alarm, but I came to ease your concerns.” She appeared to be around thirty, her bearing graceful and composed, her every movement divine—yet none could tell who she was. She asked the three, “Are you married?” They all replied that they were not. The Lady said, “I have three daughters, each of surpassing beauty and virtue, who would make fitting matches for you three gentlemen.” The three bowed in thanks. The Lady then lingered, ordering separate courtyards built for each of them. In the blink of an eye, painted halls and towering pavilions materialized as if conjured from the clouds.

The next day, carriages arrived, their wheels rumbling, accompanied by attendants more splendid than those of any noble house. The gleam of their robes and vehicles lit the earth, their fragrance perfuming the mountains and valleys. The three daughters descended from their carriages, each seventeen or eighteen years old. The Lady led them into the hall and invited the three men to take their seats. The feast was lavish, the wine and delicacies beyond anything in the mortal world, many of the fruits unfamiliar. The three men could scarcely believe their fortune. The Lady gestured to her daughters and said, “Each is to be wed to one of you.” They rose from their seats to bow in gratitude. Dozens of maidservants, radiant as immortals, were sent to attend the brides.

That night, after the wedding rites were completed, the Lady addressed the three men: “What men value most is life, and what they desire most is rank. If you keep this secret for a hundred days, I will grant you longevity beyond this world and positions at the pinnacle of the court.” The three bowed again, though they fretted over their own ignorance and lack of refinement. The Lady reassured them, “Have no fear. I am the sovereign of this earthly realm. I shall summon Confucius.”

In an instant, Confucius arrived, fully robed and girded with a sword. The Lady stood solemnly and greeted him with a slight bow, then said, “My three sons-in-law wish to study. You shall guide them.” Confucius instructed the three, pointing out the titles of the Six Classics. They understood everything at once, grasping the great principles as if they had long been familiar with them. When he had finished, Confucius took his leave.

The Lady then summoned the Duke of Zhou, who revealed to them the Mysterious Woman’s military talismans and the secret jade tokens of the *Yuhuang*. The three mastered them without omission. As they sat again, a messenger arrived bearing a letter from Princess Wenle, along with an imperial seal. The letter urged them to strive onward, for the court’s decree had temporarily humbled their lofty aspirations. Upon reaching the capital, they were received by nobles and officials, exchanging only the briefest courtesies before being appointed Grand Masters of the Heir Apparent and enfeoffed as Dukes. When they returned to the mountains, they were made Hanlin Academicians, and poets composed verses to see them off.

---

**Shuoshi of Jingzhou**
In Jingzhou, by the Li River, stand two stones resembling gates, called Shuoshi. During the Yonghe era of the Jin, two celestial beings, clad in snow-white robes and caps, alighted upon the stones and rested for ten days before departing. All the locals witnessed this.

**Master Pan of Cao Bridge**
At Fuye Abbey in Cao Bridge, Hangzhou, there lived a Master Pan, a man of ample means who embraced generosity and hospitality, aiding others with both deeds and virtue. One day, a youth of striking and uncommon appearance arrived at the abbey and addressed Master Pan: “I have long heard of your virtue and righteousness, of your aid to those in dire straits. I humbly seek refuge in the thatched hut behind your bamboo grove for two months to evade a calamity. May I impose upon your kindness?” He added, “If you grant this request, do not fear I will burden you, nor worry over provisions. I ask only for two *dou* of wine, which will suffice for sixty days.”

Though Master Pan could not fathom the youth’s origins, he gladly agreed upon hearing of his plight. The youth then concealed himself in the thatched hut. No one came searching for him, and he neither ate nor drank. When the sixty days had passed, he emerged to bow in gratitude. Calmly, he asked Master Pan, “Have you received any talismanic scriptures?” Master Pan replied, “I have attained the middle covenant of the *Dongxuan*, though I dare not yet delve into the highest teachings.”

The youth said, “Your rank is already exalted, but I have received the first stage of the *Zhengyi Jiuzhou Sheling Lu*. I offer it to you in repayment.” He then burned incense before the Heavenly Worthy and transmitted the names of the *Sheling* and the divine officers and generals. At his summons, soldiers and cavalry appeared at once. When the rites were complete, he instructed them, “After this transmission, you shall follow and protect Master Pan as you do me now.” The soldiers then vanished.

The youth further told Master Pan, “In the main hall, arrange a platform with a bed and altar. Burn incense, sit in reverence, and you will know all matters of good and ill within the Nine Provinces and beyond. But do not defile it with blood or meat, lest you incur unseen retribution. If you maintain purity and caution, you may attain the immortality of the divine transcendents.” With that, he vanished, and none knew where he had gone.

The three grew even more alarmed. The servant and nursemaids spoke soothingly to reassure them, adding that the Lady herself would arrive shortly. chunks.original_text: 潘即设榻隐几，坐於中堂。 须臾，四海之内，事无巨细，一一知之。 如是旬日，为灵官传报，颇甚谊聒。 潘勃然曰：我闲人也。 四远之事，何须知之！ 严约灵官，不使传报，答曰：职司不宜旷阙。 所报益多，约之不已，潘乃食肉啖蒜以却之，三五日，所报之声渐远，灵官不复至以亡。 一夕，少年来曰：吾轻传真诀，以罹谴责。 师犯污真灵，罪当冥考，念以前来相容之恩，不可坐观沦陷。 别受一卫，广行阴功，救人疾苦，用赎前过。 不尔，当堕於幽狱矣。 潘自啖荤食之后，自知已失，及闻斯说，忧惧异常。 少年乃取米屑，和之为人形，长四五寸，置於壁窦中，又授玉子符两道，戒潘曰：民有疾苦息难来求救者，当问粉人，以知灾祟源本，然以吾符救之，勿取钱，务在积功赎过耳。 勤行不替，十年后我当复来。 自是潘以朱篆救人，桔灾镯疾，赴之者如市。 十余年，年少#4复至，淹留逾月，多话诸天方外之事，然后别去。 岁余，潘乃无疾而终，疑其得尸解之道也。 相国卢钧 相国卢钧，进士射策，为尚书郎。 以疾求出为均州刺史。 到郡，疾稍加，赢瘠而耐#5见人，常於郡后山斋，养性独处，左右接侍亦皆远去，非公召，莫敢前也。 忽有一人，衣饰故弊，瑜垣而入，公请之，云姓王，问其#6自，云山中来。 公笑而谓之曰：即王山人也，此来何以相教？ 王曰：公之高贵，位极人臣，而寿不永，灾运方染，由是有沉绵之疾，故相救耳。 山斋无水，公欲召人力取汤茶之属，王止之，以腰巾蘸於井中，解丹一粒，捩腰巾之水，以咽丹。 与约#7曰：此后五日，疾当已#8康愈倍常，复三年，当有大息，勤#9立阴功，救人悯物为意。 此时当再来，相遇在夏之初也。 自是卢、公疾愈，旬日平复。 明年，解印还京，署盥铁判官。 夏四月，於本务东门道左，忽见山人寻至卢宅，喜#10而言曰：君今年第二限终，为灾极重，以君在郡，去年雪冤狱，活三人之命，灾已息矣，只此月内三五日不康#11，已固#12无忧也。 翌日，山人使#13二仆持铁十千，於狗脊坡分施贫病而已。 自后复去，云二十三年五月五日午时，可令·一道士於万山顶相#14候，此时君节制汉上，当有丹华相授，勿愆期也。 自是公历任清切#15，便蕃贵重，而后出镇汉南之明，年已二十三年矣。 及期，命道士牛知微，五日午时，登万山之顶。 山人在焉，以金丹二粒，使知微吞之，谓曰：子有道气，而无阴功，未契道品，勤更宜修也。 以金丹十粒授於公，曰：当享上寿，无息修炼，世限既毕，伫还蓬宫矣。 与知微相揖别#16，忽不复见。 其后知微年八十余，状貌常如三十许。 卢公年仅九十，耳目聪明，气力不衰，既终之后，异香盈室也 李公佐 李公佐，举进士后，为锺陵从事，有仆夫，自布衣执役，勤瘁昼夕，恭谨迨三十年，公佐不知其异人也。 一旦告去，留诗一章。 其辞曰：我有衣中珠，不嫌衣上尘，我有长生．理，不厌有生身，江南神仙窟，吾当混其真。 不嫌市井谊，来救人问人，苏子迹已往，注云苏耽是也颛蒙事可亲，公佐字颛蒙莫言东海变，天地有长春。 自是而去，出门不知所之，邻里见其距跃，凌空而去。
chunks.translated_text:
Pan then arranged a couch and a low table, sitting reverently in the central hall. In an instant, he knew all matters great and small within the Four Seas. For ten days thus, the divine officers relayed reports, their messages incessant and clamorous. Pan grew indignant and said, “I am but a man of leisure. Why must I know the affairs of distant lands?” He strictly forbade the divine officers from delivering reports. They replied, “Our duties may not be neglected.” As the reports grew more frequent and his prohibitions went unheeded, Pan resorted to eating meat and garlic to repel them. After three to five days, the voices of the reports gradually receded, and the divine officers no longer came—vanishing entirely.

One evening, the youth reappeared and said, “I lightly transmitted the true formula and have thus incurred punishment. You have defiled the divine numen, and your offense warrants dark torment. Yet, mindful of our past forbearance, I cannot stand by and watch you fall. Seek another guardian, broadly perform hidden merits, and relieve the suffering of others to atone for your transgressions. Otherwise, you shall descend into the nether prison.” After consuming meat and garlic, Pan had known he had erred, and upon hearing these words, he was filled with extraordinary dread.

The youth then took rice crumbs and molded them into human figures, each four or five inches tall, placing them in a wall niche. He also bestowed two jade talismans upon Pan, admonishing him, “When those afflicted by suffering or calamity come seeking aid, consult the powder figures to discern the source of their misfortune, then use my talismans to save them. Do not accept money; your duty lies in accumulating merit to atone for your faults. Persevere without fail, and in ten years, I shall return.” Thereafter, Pan used cinnabar talismans to rescue others, dispelling disasters and curing illnesses. Those who sought him came like a throng to a marketplace.

Over ten years later, the youth reappeared, staying for over a month. He spoke at length of matters beyond the heavens before taking his leave. A year later, Pan passed away without illness, leading others to suspect he had attained the Dao of *shijie* (corpse liberation).

---

**Minister Lu Jun**
Minister Lu Jun passed the imperial examination and served as a gentleman of the Ministry of Works. Due to illness, he requested to be appointed prefect of Junzhou. Upon arriving in the prefecture, his condition worsened, leaving him emaciated yet still able to receive visitors. He often retreated to a mountain studio behind the prefectural hall to cultivate his nature in solitude. His attendants kept their distance, and none dared approach without summons.

Suddenly, a man in tattered clothing climbed over the wall and entered. Lu invited him in, and the man gave his surname as Wang. Asked of his origins, he replied he had come from the mountains. Lu smiled and said, “So you are Master Wang of the mountains. What instruction do you bring?” Wang replied, “Your Excellency holds the highest rank among men, yet your lifespan is not long, and misfortune now befalls you. This has brought lingering illness, which is why I come to your aid.”

Noting the lack of water in the studio, Lu intended to summon servants to fetch tea, but Wang stopped him. Drawing water from the well with his sash, he dissolved a cinnabar pellet in it, wrung out the sash, and had Lu swallow the liquid. He then made an agreement: “In five days, your illness will be cured, and your health will surpass your former state. After three years, you will face a great trial. Diligently perform hidden merits, and take compassion for others as your intent. I shall return then, and we will meet at the beginning of summer.”

Thereafter, Lu’s illness improved, and within ten days, he fully recovered. The following year, he resigned his post and returned to the capital, where he was appointed vice-director of the Bureau of Iron and Salt. In the fourth month of summer, as he walked along the eastern road outside his office, he suddenly saw the mountain man arrive at his residence. The man rejoiced and said, “This year marks the end of your second life limit, and the calamity was severe. However, while in the prefecture last year, you exonerated a wrongful conviction and saved three lives, thereby averting the disaster. You will only face three to five days of discomfort this month, but there is no cause for concern.”

The next day, the mountain man sent two servants with ten thousand coins to distribute among the poor and sick at Gouji Slope. He then departed, saying, “On the fifth day of the fifth month, twenty-three years hence, at noon, have a Daoist await me atop Wanshan Peak. By then, you will govern Hanzhong, and I shall bestow upon you the Elixir of Golden Radiance. Do not miss the appointed time.”

Thereafter, Lu held a succession of esteemed posts, rising in prominence and favor. Later, he was appointed military governor of Hanzhong, and twenty-three years had passed. At the appointed time, he sent the Daoist Niu Zhiwei to ascend Wanshan Peak at noon on the fifth day. The mountain man was already there. He gave Niu two golden elixir pellets to swallow, saying, “You possess the qi of the Dao but lack hidden merits and have not yet attained the rank of the Dao. You must cultivate further.” He then presented Lu with ten golden elixir pellets, saying, “You shall enjoy a long life. Do not cease your cultivation. When your worldly limit is complete, I await your return to Penglai Palace.” He bowed to Niu and took his leave, vanishing without a trace.

Later, Niu lived to over eighty, yet his appearance remained as that of a man in his thirties. Minister Lu lived to nearly ninety, his senses sharp and his vitality unwaning. After his passing, an extraordinary fragrance filled the room.

---

**Li Gongzuo**
After passing the imperial examination, Li Gongzuo served as an aide in Zhongling. He had a servant who, though a commoner, had diligently and reverently served him day and night for nearly thirty years. Gongzuo never suspected he was an extraordinary person. One day, the servant announced his departure, leaving behind a poem:

*I possess a pearl within my robe,*
*Unmindful of the dust upon it.*
*I hold the principle of long life,*
*Unwearied by this mortal form.*
*The Jiangnan is a cave of immortals,*
*Where I shall merge with the true.*
*Unashamed of the marketplace’s clamor,*
*I come to save the people of the world.*
*Su Dan’s traces are long past,*
*(Note: Su Dan is meant.)*
*The ignorant may yet be befriended.*
*(Gongzuo’s courtesy name was “The Ignorant.”)*
*Do not speak of the Eastern Sea’s transformation,*
*For heaven and earth know eternal spring.*

After this, he departed, and no one knew where he had gone. Neighbors saw him leap into the air and vanish into the sky.

chunks.original_text: 王子芝 王子芝，字仙苗，自云河南堠氏人。 常游京洛问。 耆老云：五十年来见之，状貌恒如四十许，莫知其甲子也。 好养气而嗜酒。 故蒲帅琅哪公重盈作镇之初年，仙苗届于紫极宫，王令待之甚厚，又闻其嗜酒，日以二磕饷之。 问日，仙苗因出，遇一樵者，荷檐於宫门，貌非常也，意甚异焉。 因市其薪，厚偿厥价，樵者得金，亦不让而去。 子芝令人蹑其后以问之，樵者径趋酒肆，尽饮酒以归。 他日复来，谓子芝曰：是酒佳即佳矣，然殊不及解县石氏之酝也，余适自彼来，恨向者无倡，不果尽於斟酌。 子芝因降阶执手，与之拥炉，祈於樵者曰：石氏芳嘐可致不？ 樵者欢之，因丹笔书符一，置於火上。 姻未绝，有小竖立于所，樵者动之#17，尔领尊师之仆，挈此二磕，第往石家取酒，吾待与尊师一醉。 时既昏夜，门已肩禁，小竖谓子芝仆曰#18：可闭目。 因搭其头，人与酒壶偕出自门隙，已及解县，买酒而还。 因与子芝共倾焉，其甘醇郁烈，非世所俦。 中宵，樵者谓子芝曰：子已醉矣，余召一客伴子饮，可乎？ 子芝曰：可复书一朱符置火上#19瞬息#20问，闻异香满室。 有一人甚堂堂，美鬓眉，紫袍，秉简揖坐，樵曰：而#21坐。 引满而巡，二壶且褫，樵者烧一铁筋，以暖紫衣者，云：子可去。 时束方明矣。 遂各执别，樵者因谓子芝曰：识向来人否？ 少顷可造河渍庙睹之。 子芝送樵者讫，因过庙所，睹夜来共饮者，乃神耳，铁筋之验宛然。 赵均郎中时在幕府，自验此事，弘文馆校书郎苏税亦寓於中条，甚熟踪迹。 其后子芝再遇樵仙，别传修炼之诀，且为地仙矣。 何亮 何亮者，商山束阴驿厅子也。

Wang Zizhi, styled Xianmiao, claimed to be a native of Houshi in Henan. He often traveled between the capital and Luoyang. Elders said that for fifty years they had seen him, his appearance ever like that of a man in his forties, none knowing his true age. He cultivated qi and was fond of wine.

In the early years of Pu Prefecture’s Lord Langya Chongying’s governorship, Xianmiao arrived at the Purple Ultimate Palace. The prefect, Wang, treated him with great generosity and, learning of his love for wine, daily sent him two flasks. One day, as Xianmiao was leaving, he encountered a woodcutter at the palace gate, carrying firewood on his shoulder. The man’s appearance was extraordinary, and Xianmiao found him most unusual. He purchased the woodcutter’s firewood, paying him generously, and the woodcutter accepted the silver without demur and departed. Xianmiao sent someone to follow him and inquire. The woodcutter went straight to a tavern, drank all the wine he could, and then returned home.

The next day, the woodcutter returned and said to Xianmiao, “This wine is indeed fine, but it cannot compare to the brew of the Shi family in Jie County. I have just come from there and regret that I had no companion before to share it fully.” Xianmiao descended the steps, took his hand, and sat with him by the brazier. He entreated the woodcutter, saying, “Can the Shi family’s fragrant wine be obtained?” The woodcutter was pleased and wrote a vermilion talisman with cinnabar, placing it in the fire. Before the smoke had dissipated, a young servant appeared. The woodcutter commanded him, saying, “You, take the master’s servant and these two flasks, go to the Shi household, and fetch wine. I shall wait to drink with the master until we are drunk.” It was already deep night, and the gates were barred. The young servant said to Xianmiao’s servant, “Close your eyes.” He then lifted the servant’s head, and man and wine jars slipped through the gate’s crack. In an instant, they reached Jie County, purchased the wine, and returned. They poured it together, and its sweetness, richness, and potency were beyond anything in the mortal world.

At midnight, the woodcutter said to Xianmiao, “You are drunk. Shall I summon a guest to accompany you in drinking?” Xianmiao replied, “Very well.” The woodcutter again wrote a vermilion talisman and placed it in the fire. In the blink of an eye, a strange fragrance filled the room. A man of imposing presence entered, his brows and temples handsome, clad in purple robes, holding a tablet. He bowed and sat. The woodcutter said, “Be seated.” They drank deeply in turn, and the two flasks were soon emptied. The woodcutter heated an iron poker and warmed the purple-robed man, saying, “You may go.” By then, dawn was breaking in the east. They each took their leave, and the woodcutter said to Xianmiao, “Do you recognize the man who just left? In a little while, go to the Heze Temple and you will see him.” Xianmiao saw the woodcutter off, then visited the temple. There he saw the man with whom he had drunk the night before—it was the temple deity, the iron poker’s mark still plainly visible.

At the time, Vice Director Zhao Jun was in the prefectural office, and he personally verified this matter. Su Shui, Proofreader of the Hongwen Library, was also residing in Zhongtiao and was well acquainted with the details. Later, Xianmiao encountered the woodcutter immortal again, who transmitted to him the secrets of cultivation, and he became an earthbound immortal.

He Liang was a stable attendant at the East Slope Post Station in Shang Mountain.

chunks.original_text: 役二十年，尝谦谨自持，不敢违怠。 一日寒，其雨雪交至，道绝行旅。 有一道士，冒雨而至，衣装皆湿。 历诣诸店，皆闭门不容。 亮见而哀之，延就驿廊下，炽火设食以待之。 一夕而行去，将踌跚，曰：荷君此恩，不可无报。 因壶中取丹一粒，令吞之。 谓曰：大期内可以无疾矣。 言讫而去，何亮年已四十余，自此筋力愈充，无复疾苦。 乾符初，年九十余矣，状貌四十岁，齿发不衰。 信都先生冯君涓，尝召问其事。 远近之人，亦具道之，余得此说於信都先生焉。

Having served for twenty years, He Liang always maintained humility and caution, never daring to be negligent or idle. One cold day, rain and snow fell together, cutting off all travelers on the road. A Daoist, braving the storm, arrived with his robes and belongings soaked through. He approached every inn, but all doors were shut and none would take him in. Seeing this, Liang pitied him and invited him beneath the post station’s eaves, where he kindled a fire and prepared food for him. The Daoist stayed the night before departing. As he was about to leave, he hesitated and said, “I cannot repay your kindness without some token.” From his gourd, he took a single elixir pellet and instructed Liang to swallow it. “Within your allotted span,” he said, “you will suffer no illness.” With these words, he left.

He Liang was already over forty at the time, yet from then on his strength and vigor only grew, and he knew no more sickness or pain. By the early years of the Qianfu era, he was over ninety, yet his appearance remained that of a man in his forties—his teeth and hair showed no sign of decline. Master Feng Junjuan of Xindu once summoned him to inquire about these events. People far and near all recounted the same story, and I learned of it from Master Feng.

chunks.original_text: 薛长官 薛长官者，尝与友人李生自京师同志访道，同游名山，数年未有所遇。 而薛南入五岭，言隐罗浮，其志弥笃。 李生中道而辗，复归京师，游宦不偶，年迫衰暮。 与薛相别三十余年，交亲益疏，骨肉沦丧，晚岁杖策，诣罗浮访之，果与薛相见。 薛柄止且久，道术既成，风姿秀颖，肌若水玉。 山中华轩层阁，风亭月榭，迨非人世所有。 见李容状枯瘁，深所悯恻，谓之曰：子虽欲柄息於此，然终不可久驻。 因以金宝厚拯之，命女妓酣宴以饯之。 将行，顾见其齿俱缺，－问其故。 云：前因弄球子所损，收击在衣带中。 取而窥之，令女妓刮去垢污，薛以小刀子剖其缺处，复安二齿，而遣之，戒以木语。 及达山下，齿已牢矣。 自是十余年，生诸齿皆朽落，所安者，宛而不动。 容师张公自给事中出，领兹镇，岁余病瘴虐累月弥甚，公耽尚释氏，众有符药，或言有效者，皆不见信。 骨肉将吏，深以为忧。 副使信都先生冯君，密谓公之亲吏曰：罗浮薛长官，深有道术，拯人疾苦，远近赖之，可使一介，持信以求其救也。 由是命使访之，果得其居处。 薛闻而哀焉，谓使者曰：谢张公远遗方物山中，无纸笔，不复寓书，所疾无以为忧，使至之后，可扫洒庭宇，洁斋三日，自当有应。 如其言，既至三日，一宅闻异香气，亦无所有，而张公廖矣。 复使人资信币入山致谢，使者迷失旧路，竟不知其处所。 此盖地仙之俦也，余亦於信都先生得之矣。 神仙感遇传卷之三竟 #1此句《云笈七签》作『处襟大度』。 #2此句《云笈七签》作『行功济人』。 #3『茅』，《云笈七签》作『苑』。 #4『年少』，《云笈七签》作『少年』。 #5此句《云笈七签》作『不耐见人』。 #6此句《云笈七签》作『问其所自』。 #7此句《云笈七签》作r『以丹与之。 因约日』。 #8『已』字，《云搜七签》无。 #9『勤』，《云笈七签》作『劝』。 #10『喜』，《云笈七签》作『会』。 #11『不康』，《云笈七签》作－小不康』。 #12『固』，《云笈七签》作『困』。 #13此句《云笈七签》作『山人令使二仆持钱十千』。 #14《云笈七签》无『相』字。 #15此句《云笈七签》作『自是公扬历任清切』。 #16此句《云笈七签》作『与知微揖别』。 #17此句《云笈七签》作『樵者救之日』。 #18此句《云笈七签》作『小竖渭其仆日』。 #19此句《云笈七签》作『可复书朱符置火上』。 #20此句《云笈七签》作『瞬息』，无『问』字。 #21此句《云笈七签》作『樵曰：坐』。 神仙感遇传卷之四 广成先生杜光庭纂
chunks.translated_text:
Officer Xue

Officer Xue once journeyed with his friend Li to the capital, both sharing the same resolve to seek the Dao. Together they wandered through famous mountains for years, yet met with no success. Later, Xue headed south into the Five Ridges, declaring his intent to seclude himself on Mount Luofu, his determination growing ever more steadfast. Li, however, turned back midway and returned to the capital, where his official career proved ill-fated. As old age pressed upon him, he and Xue had been parted for over thirty years, their bond of friendship and kinship long faded. In his later years, leaning on a staff, Li made his way to Mount Luofu to seek him out—and indeed, the two were reunited.

By then, Xue had dwelled there for many years, his Daoist arts perfected. His bearing was refined and elegant, his skin smooth as jade. Amid the mountain’s peaks stood pavilions and terraces, wind-swept kiosks and moonlit pavilions—all unlike anything found in the mortal world. Seeing Li’s emaciated and withered appearance, Xue was deeply moved with pity. He said, “Though you wish to stay here, you cannot remain for long.” He then gave Li a generous gift of gold and treasures, and ordered his female musicians to hold a feast in his honor.

As Li was about to depart, Xue noticed his teeth were all missing. When asked the reason, Li explained, “Previously, while playing with a ball, I damaged them. I kept the broken teeth in my sash.” He took them out for Xue to examine. Xue had the female musicians clean off the grime, then used a small knife to scrape the broken edges before reattaching two teeth. He sent Li on his way with a warning not to speak of it. By the time Li reached the foot of the mountain, the teeth had already firmly set. Over the next ten years, all of Li’s other teeth rotted and fell out, yet the two that had been restored remained firmly in place, unchanged.

Master Rong, a teacher surnamed Zhang, had been appointed from the position of *Geishizhong* to govern this region. After more than a year, he fell gravely ill from miasmic vapors, his condition worsening month by month. A devotee of Buddhism, he placed no trust in talismans or medicines, even when others claimed they were effective. His family, retainers, and officers were deeply concerned. Vice-Commissioner Feng, the Master of Xindu, secretly told one of Zhang’s close attendants, “Officer Xue of Mount Luofu possesses profound Daoist arts and has relieved many of their suffering. People near and far rely on him. You should send a messenger bearing a token of sincerity to seek his aid.”

Thus, a messenger was dispatched to find him, and his dwelling was indeed located. Upon hearing the request, Xue took pity and said to the messenger, “Convey my thanks to Prefect Zhang for sending gifts from afar to this mountain retreat. I have no paper or brush here, so I cannot send a letter in reply. As for his illness, there is no need for concern. Once the messenger arrives, have them sweep and purify the courtyard and maintain a strict fast for three days—there will naturally be a response.”

Following his instructions, on the third day, the entire residence was filled with a strange and fragrant aroma, though nothing else was seen. Yet Prefect Zhang’s illness was cured. Another messenger was sent bearing gifts and silk to express gratitude, but this time, the envoy lost the path and could never again find the place.

This was surely one of the ranks of earthbound immortals. I, too, learned of this account from the Master of Xindu.

*Records of Divine Immortals’ Encounters, Scroll Three* concludes here.

chunks.original_text: 谢墦 谢墦者，蜀川人也。 幼而好道，尝与三人同志，约为弟兄，同游诸山，博采方术。 因相与於峨眉山门誓曰：此山神仙所居，必有求道之所。 我等三人，於此相别，各入一谷中，随所投诣，看有见遇否。 讫分行，墦入木皮谷，约五六里，逢四老人，会坐巨石之上，前有大盘烹肉，共食之次。 召墦令坐，揖令食肉。 墦告之曰：某志神仙之道，游历名山，久绝荤血，非敢娇妄矣。 老人喜曰：子既求道，但入此谷，当有所遇。 墦即诣谷中，行数十里，见有台阁华盛，迨非人世所居。 入门有道士数人，问其何以至此，具以所至启之。 一人熟视墦良久，引至大殿之上，像设俨然。 天尊前有经书，委积案几。 此人令墦闭目，信手探取一卷，因即授之曰：此天文大篆也，行之可以长生度世，可以积功救人，此非汝久居之处，便可去矣。 墦辞道流，得经出山，却至谷口，宿於民家。 有小儿堕沸汤中，数处糜烂，举室惊痛，无门救之。 墦视天文中，有注字可治者，乃书其文，为灰调水洗之，边巡都愈。 自此常以天篆阴功救人。 蒙其效者，不可胜计。 相国豳公都尉镇成都，招致墦於门下，待以异礼。 及朝觐京师，墦亦随至长安。 一旦，豳公子弟暴疾，国医盈门，莫能效。 公忽记墦神篆之力，促令召之，才至，授毫书之，应手而愈。 金帛赐与，凡十数万，一无所取。 其后归蜀，复游诸山，不知所之。 郑又玄 郑又玄者，名家子，居长安中。 其小与邻舍闻丘氏子，偕学於师氏。 又玄性桥率，自以门望清贵，而问丘寒贱，往往戏而骂之曰：尔非类，而与吾偕学，吾虽不语，尔宁不愧於心乎！ 闻丘默有暂色，岁余乃死。 又十年，又玄明经上第，补蜀州参军。 既至官，郡守命作尉#1唐兴。 有同舍仇生者，大贾之子，年始冠。 其家资产万计，日与又玄宴游，又玄累受仇生金钱之赂，然以仇生非士族，未尝以礼貌接之。 一日，又玄置酒高会，而仇生不得预。 及酒阑，有#2谓又玄曰：仇生与子同舍，子会宴，而仇生不预，岂其罪耶？ 又玄暂而召仇。 既至，又玄以卮饮之，生辞不能引满，固辞。 又玄怒，骂曰：尔市井之陀，徒知锥刀，何僭居官秩耶！ 且吾与尔为伍，尔已幸矣，又何敢辞酒乎！ 因振衣起，仇生暂耿而退，弃官闭门，月余病卒。 明年又玄官罢，侨居蒙阳，而常好黄老之道。 闻蜀山有＇昊道士，又玄高其风，往而诣之，愿为门弟子。 留之且十年，未禀所受，又玄稍惰，辞之而还。 其后因入长安，宿#3褒城。 逆旅有一童子，十余岁，貌秀而慧，又玄与语，机辩万变，又玄深奇之。 童子谓又玄曰：我与君，故人有年矣，省之乎？ 又玄曰：忘之矣。 童子曰：吾生闲丘氏，居长安中，与子偕学，而子以我为非类，尝骂辱我。 又为仇氏子作尉唐兴，与子同舍，子受我厚赂#4，而谓我为市井之虻，何吾子骄傲之甚也！ 子以衣缨之家，而凌侮於物，非道也哉！ 我太清真人也。
chunks.translated_text:
She Fan

She Fan was a native of Shu. From childhood, he was drawn to the Dao, and once formed a bond with three like-minded companions, swearing brotherhood. Together, they roamed the mountains, gathering esoteric arts. At the gates of Mount Emei, they made a pact: “This mountain is the abode of immortals—there must be places here where the Dao may be sought. Let us three part ways, each entering a different valley, to see if any of us encounters anything.”

They separated, and Fan entered the Valley of Wooden Bark. After five or six *li*, he came upon four old men seated on a great boulder, a large platter of simmering meat before them as they ate. They beckoned Fan to sit and offered him a portion. Fan declined, saying, “I seek the Dao of immortals and have long since renounced meat and blood—this is no affectation.”

The old men smiled and said, “Since you seek the Dao, enter this valley, and you will surely find what you seek.”

Fan proceeded into the valley. After several dozen *li*, he saw pavilions and terraces of such splendor that they could not have been of this world. At the gate stood several Daoists, who asked how he had come there. He recounted his journey in full. One of them studied Fan intently for a long while, then led him to a great hall where statues stood in solemn array. Before the image of the Heavenly Worthy lay stacks of scriptures upon the table. The Daoist told Fan to close his eyes, reach out at random, and take one volume. He then handed it to him, saying, “This is the *Celestial Script in Great Seal Script*. Practicing it will grant you longevity and transcendence, allow you to accumulate merit and save others. But this is not a place for you to linger—you must go now.”

Fan took leave of the Daoists, departed the mountain with the scripture, and lodged at a household near the valley’s entrance. There, a child had fallen into boiling water, his flesh scalded in several places. The entire household was in distress, with no means of saving him. Fan consulted the *Celestial Script* and found a passage marked for such treatment. He transcribed the characters, mixed the ashes with water, and washed the child’s wounds—by the time he had finished, the child was fully healed.

From then on, Fan often used the *Celestial Script* to perform hidden acts of merit and save others. Those who benefited from his powers were beyond counting. When Lord Bin, the Military Commissioner, governed Chengdu, he summoned Fan to his service and treated him with exceptional courtesy. When the lord later journeyed to the capital for an audience, Fan accompanied him to Chang’an.

One day, a member of Lord Bin’s family fell gravely ill. Physicians filled the house, but none could effect a cure. The lord suddenly recalled Fan’s divine script, and hastily summoned him. Fan arrived, took up his brush, and wrote the characters—no sooner had he finished than the patient recovered. Gold and silk were offered as gifts, amounting to tens of thousands, but Fan accepted nothing.

Later, he returned to Shu and wandered among the mountains, vanishing without a trace.

---

Zheng Youxuan

Zheng Youxuan was the scion of a noble family in Chang’an. As a boy, he studied alongside a neighbor’s son, Wenqiu, under the same master. Youxuan was proud and blunt, considering his lineage pure and exalted, while Wenqiu was of humble birth. Often, he mocked and berated him, saying, “You are no kin to me—how dare you study at my side? Even if I say nothing, do you feel no shame?”

Wenqiu’s face darkened with resentment, and within a year, he died.

A decade later, Youxuan passed the imperial examinations with distinction and was appointed as a military advisor in Shuzhou. Upon taking office, the prefect ordered him to serve as a magistrate in Tangxing. Among his colleagues was a young man named Qiu, the son of a wealthy merchant, who had just come of age. His family’s wealth was vast, and he often feasted and roamed with Youxuan, showering him with gold and gifts. Yet Youxuan, considering Qiu beneath his station, never treated him with proper courtesy.

One day, Youxuan hosted a grand banquet but did not invite Qiu. As the feast drew to a close, someone said to Youxuan, “Qiu shares your office—why was he not invited? Has he committed some offense?”

Youxuan hesitated, then summoned Qiu. When he arrived, Youxuan handed him a goblet, but Qiu declined, saying he could not drink it all. Youxuan grew furious and cursed him: “You lowborn cur, fit only for counting coins—how dare you presume to hold office? That I even deign to associate with you is your good fortune—how dare you refuse my wine!”

He rose in a huff, and Qiu, his face flushed with anger, withdrew. He resigned his post, shut himself away, and within a month, died of illness.

The following year, Youxuan’s term ended, and he took up residence in Mengyang, where he developed an interest in the teachings of the Yellow Emperor and Laozi. Hearing of a certain Master Wu in the mountains of Shu, Youxuan admired his reputation and sought him out, wishing to become his disciple. He remained with the master for nearly a decade but received no transmission of teachings. Growing restless, he took his leave and returned.

Later, while passing through Chang’an, he lodged in Baocheng. At the inn, he met a boy of ten or so, fair and quick-witted. Youxuan spoke with him, and the boy’s wit and eloquence astonished him. The boy said, “You and I have been old acquaintances for years—do you not remember?”

Youxuan replied, “I have forgotten.”

The boy said, “I was once Wenqiu, living in Chang’an. You studied with me but deemed me unworthy, insulting and humiliating me. Later, I was reborn as Qiu, the son of a merchant family, and served as a magistrate in Tangxing. You accepted my generous gifts yet called me a ‘lowborn cur.’ How could you be so arrogant? You, born to a family of scholars, trampled upon others—was that the Way?”

“I am a Perfected One of the Great Clarity.”

chunks.original_text: 上帝以尔有道气，使我生于人问，与汝为友，将授汝神仙之诀，而汝轻果高傲，终不能得其道。 吁，可悲哉！ 言讫，忽不复见。 又玄既悟其罪，而意以暂作而卒矣。 卢道流 卢道流者，不知何许人也。 年七十余，卖卜於洛阳市。 忽店作十余日，异常危笃。 闻程修已处士，来往二京，颇有神奇之迹，盖得道者也。 卢以店疾告之，程於瓠中出丹砂，细如芥子，於白茶碗中，滴酒研碎，又书碗子内作二天使字，以授於卢，并酒服之，店即顿愈。 无何，自玄元观，欲入城路。 经谷水，暑热既甚，因浴於水中。 顷之，谷水暴溢，水头丈余，卢为水所流，已百余步。 河侧有二天使促命锄瓜人，涉流救之，仅得而免。 及岸，则不复见二天使○免此漂流之厄，书二天使字，以潜救之耳。 天复中，程至长安，谓人曰：五岭可以避地，托求丹砂，入桂阳，不知所之。 成生 成生者，其家巨富，世居零口，伯叔数人，其第七叔好道，早年冠褐，来往华阴山，时或暂归。 自咸通后，不知所在。 洎大稷犯关，昭宗束幸，成生骨肉沦散，生计困穷。 忽一日，其叔还家，悯恻嗟痛，留止数日，因与成生之子，往同州砂苑中。 至所居，即甲第宏敞，亭台崇邃，有若宫门焉，立成生之子於门外，良久，持衣服器皿一吧，以授之，令归赡家。 至即数万金矢，成生惊异，知季父之得道也。 翌日，与其子复往寻之，无复知处所，成生由是赡足。 其门外墙角有石筝，以捍车马，凡五六十年。 其叔令移於庭内，生疑其异，因攻錾之，得丹砂伍斤。 邻里知之，或传於外，为军中有力者所夺。 惜哉！ 疑其非世之丹砂，迨神仙之上药者乎？ 而失之哉。 徐定国
chunks.translated_text:
The Celestial Emperor, seeing that you possessed the qi of the Dao, caused me to be born among men to befriend you, intending to bestow upon you the secrets of divine transcendence. Yet you were reckless, haughty, and arrogant—thus you could never attain the Way. Alas, how lamentable! With these words, he suddenly vanished.

Youxuan, awakening to his sins, fell gravely ill and soon perished.

---

**Lu Daoliu**
Lu Daoliu was a man of unknown origins. At over seventy years of age, he told fortunes in the markets of Luoyang. One day, he fell severely ill for more than ten days, his condition growing perilous. Hearing that the recluse Cheng Xiuyi often traveled between the two capitals and had performed many wondrous deeds—being one who had attained the Dao—Lu informed him of his illness. Cheng took from his gourd a cinnabar pellet, fine as a mustard seed, and ground it in a white porcelain bowl with a few drops of wine. He then inscribed the characters for "Two Celestial Envoys" inside the bowl and gave it to Lu to drink with the wine. Lu’s illness immediately vanished.

Shortly after, as Lu was returning from Xuan Yuan Temple and nearing the city, he passed by the Valley River. The heat was oppressive, so he bathed in the water. Suddenly, the river surged, its crest rising over ten feet. Lu was swept away more than a hundred paces before two Celestial Envoys appeared on the bank, urging melon farmers to wade in and rescue him. He was barely saved. Upon reaching the shore, the two envoys vanished. It was the inscribed characters of the "Two Celestial Envoys" that had secretly delivered him from this calamity.

During the Tianfu era, Cheng arrived in Chang’an and told others, “The Five Ridges are a refuge from the world.” Claiming to seek cinnabar, he entered Guiyang and was never heard from again.

---

**Cheng Sheng**
Cheng Sheng came from an immensely wealthy family that had long resided in Lingkou. Among his uncles, the seventh was devoted to the Dao. In his early years, he donned hempen robes and wandered the Huayin Mountains, returning home only occasionally. After the Xiantong era, his whereabouts became unknown.

When the great famine breached the passes and Emperor Zhaozong fled in distress, Cheng Sheng’s family was scattered, and his livelihood reduced to poverty. One day, his uncle unexpectedly returned home, moved by pity and sorrow. He stayed for several days before taking Cheng Sheng’s son to the Sand Gardens of Tongzhou.

Upon arriving at his dwelling—a grand estate with towering pavilions and gates resembling a palace—he left the boy outside. After a long while, he returned with a bundle of clothing and utensils, which he gave to the boy to take home for his family’s support. Upon opening it, they found tens of thousands of gold coins. Cheng Sheng was astonished, realizing his uncle had attained the Dao.

The next day, he and his son returned to search for him, but his whereabouts were unknown. From then on, Cheng Sheng’s family was well provided for.

Outside the gate, a stone chime had stood for fifty or sixty years, serving as a barrier for carriages and horses. His uncle had ordered it moved into the courtyard. Suspecting it was unusual, Cheng Sheng had it chiseled open, revealing five *jin* of cinnabar. When word spread, some told others outside, and it was seized by a powerful figure in the military.

What a pity! Was this not the cinnabar of immortals, the supreme elixir of divine transcendence? And now it was lost.

**Xu Dingguo**

chunks.original_text: 徐定国者，隶籍右三军，有膂力。 大中年，诏选三十人，送轩辕先生归罗浮，定国得预其选。 既至山，托以有，疾方就药饵，因得驻留，遂执仆御之礼，以事轩辕。 时定国已六十余岁，数年，先生遣之归长安，容状益少，若奔马。 天复中，不啻百岁，才如四十人也。 京兆华原陆尊师 京兆华原砾阳界，有古观焉。 有陆．尊师者，隋朝得坐忘之道，其形质尚存。 乾宁中，有奉使北京，於绾舍中，与师相遇。 言笑如旧，交驻留旬日，话所止，官使还京，乃乞假归别墅，诣访焉。 於小殿中，见陆尊师像貌，与北都所见无异。 有姚生者持《黄庭经》。 光启初，僖宗再幸梁洋，姚为寇盗所迫，夜窜以避之，误堕此观侧井中，伤足。 乃旁穴为井害，以养其疾。 村里荒梗，竟无人到。
chunks.translated_text:
Xu Dingguo was registered in the Right Three Armies and possessed great physical strength. During the Dazhong era, an imperial edict selected thirty men to escort Master Xuanyuan to Mount Luofu, and Dingguo was among those chosen. Upon arriving at the mountain, he claimed illness and began taking medicinal preparations, thus securing permission to remain. He then served Master Xuanyuan with the rites of a servant, attending to his needs. At the time, Dingguo was already over sixty years old. After several years, the Master sent him back to Chang’an, his appearance having grown younger, swift as a galloping horse. By the Tianfu era, he was no less than a hundred years old, yet his vigor resembled that of a man of forty.

**Master Lu of Huayuan in Jingzhao**
In the boundary of Liyang in Huayuan, Jingzhao, stood an ancient Daoist abbey. There resided Master Lu, who had attained the Dao of *zuowang* (sitting in forgetfulness) during the Sui dynasty, yet his physical form remained preserved. During the Qianning era, an official on a mission to the northern capital encountered the Master in his lodgings. They conversed and laughed as old friends, staying together for ten days. Upon learning where the Master resided, the official, upon returning to the capital, requested leave to visit his villa. In a small hall, he saw the likeness of Master Lu, unchanged from their meeting in the northern capital.

There was a scholar named Yao who carried the *Huangting Jing*. At the beginning of the Guangqi era, when Emperor Xizong fled again to Liang and Yang, Yao was pursued by bandits and fled in the night to evade them. He accidentally fell into a well beside the abbey, injuring his foot. He then dug a side chamber in the well-shaft to tend to his injury. The village was desolate and overgrown, and no one came to his aid.

chunks.original_text: 以无修习之卫，但昼夜念《黄庭》、《道德》二经，自觉不饥，足疾亦愈，亦不知在井害中岁月之数也。 襄王既平，大驾归阙，有游军宿于观中，夜见光明从井中出，因访而出之。 姚生感真经所佑之力，遂为道士，居于此观焉。 明皇十仙 明皇尝梦仙子十人，御卿云而下，引於庭，各执乐悬而奏之。 其曲度清越，真仙府之音也。 乐阕，有一仙人，前而言曰：陛下知此乐乎？ 此神仙《紫云曲》也，今愿传授陛下，为圣唐正始之音，与咸韶大夏，固不同也。 上喜甚，即传授焉。 俄而寤，其余响犹若在听，且命玉笛吹而习之，尽得其节奏，欲默而不泄。 晓而听政於紫宸殿，宰臣姚崇、宋璟入奏事於上前，上倪然若不闻。 二相惧，又奏之。 上即起，下望庭麻，卒不顾。 二相益恐，趋出。 内臣高力士奏曰：宰相有所请，陛下宜面决可不？ 向者崇、璟所言，皆军国大政，而陛下卒不顾，岂二相有罪乎？ 上笑曰：我昨夕梦十仙子奏乐，日《紫云曲》，因以授我。 朕惧失其节奏，县是默而习之，因不暇听二相。 即於衣中出玉笛，以示力士。 是日，力士至中书为二相言，二相惧少解，其曲传於乐府焉。 虬须客 虬须客道兄者，不知名氏。
chunks.translated_text:
With no practice of cultivation to sustain him, he simply recited the *Huangting Jing* and the *Daode Jing* day and night. He felt no hunger, and his foot injury healed. He had no sense of how many months or years he had spent in the well-shaft.

After Xiangwang was pacified and the imperial cortege returned to the capital, a patrol of soldiers lodged at the abbey. At night, they saw a radiant light emanating from the well and, upon investigating, brought him out. Moved by the protective power of the true scriptures, Yao became a Daoist and took up residence at the abbey.

**The Ten Immortals of Emperor Ming**
Emperor Ming once dreamed of ten immortals descending on rosy clouds to his courtyard, each holding a musical instrument and playing a melody. The tune was clear and transcendent, truly the music of the immortal realm. When the music ended, one immortal stepped forward and said: *"Does Your Majesty recognize this music? This is the immortal melody *Ziyun Qu*. We now wish to transmit it to you as the proper foundation of sound for the sacred Tang. It is not the same as the *Xianchi* or *Daxia* of old."*

The emperor was overjoyed and immediately received the transmission. Upon waking, the lingering echoes still seemed to resonate in his ears. He ordered a jade flute and practiced the melody until he mastered its rhythm, resolving to keep it secret. The next morning, as he held court in the Zichen Hall, his chief ministers Yao Chong and Song Jing entered to present state affairs. The emperor sat in silence, as if he had not heard them. The two ministers grew alarmed and repeated their report. The emperor rose, descended the steps, and gazed at the officials assembled in the courtyard, yet paid them no heed. The ministers, now deeply fearful, withdrew.

The eunuch Gao Lishi then addressed the emperor: *"The chief ministers have matters to present. Should Your Majesty not grant them an audience? The matters they raised earlier concern the very security of the state, yet you ignored them. Have the ministers committed some offense?"*

The emperor laughed and said: *"Last night, I dreamed of ten immortals playing a melody called *Ziyun Qu*, which they then taught to me. I feared forgetting its rhythm, so I silently practiced it and had no time to attend to the ministers."* With that, he drew a jade flute from his robe and showed it to Gao Lishi.

That day, Gao Lishi went to the Chancellery and recounted the matter to the two ministers. Their fear abated somewhat, and the melody was later transmitted to the Music Bureau.

**The Bearded Daoist Brother**
There was a Daoist brother known as the Bearded Guest, whose name and origins were unknown.

chunks.translated_text: At the end of Emperor Yang’s reign, when the Grand Chancellor Yang Su was left in charge of Chang’an while the emperor traveled to Jiangdu, Yang held power with such arrogance and haughtiness that he scorned all worldly sentiment. Duke Wei, Li Jing, had twice sought an audience with him, and thus encountered Yang’s attendant courtesan, Hongfu. The courtesan, surnamed Zhang and known as "First," sensed that Yang’s downfall was imminent and soon abandoned him to flee with Jing. Together they departed the Western Capital, bound for Taiyuan. At an inn in Lingshi, they dismounted to rest, where they encountered the Bearded Guest. He was a man of imposing stature, with a fiery red beard, and he arrived clad in tattered robes, riding a lame donkey. He tossed his cloth sack to the ground, took out a pillow, and lay down outside, watching as Zhang combed her hair, which cascaded to the floor. She stood brushing it by the bed. Jing, observing the bearded man, grew furious and could not help but glare at him. Zhang, studying the stranger’s face intently, held her hair with one hand while shielding herself with the other, signaling Jing to suppress his anger. Once she had hastily finished combing her hair, she straightened her robes and stepped forward to ask his surname. The man outside replied, "Zhang." She said, "I, too, am surnamed Zhang—we must be sisters." She promptly bowed to him. "What is your birth order?" she asked. "Third," he replied. "And yours?" "I am the eldest," she said. They sat in a circle, cutting meat to share. The guest fed the scraps to his donkey and laughed, "Master Li is but a poor scholar—how have you come by such an extraordinary figure?" Jing recounted the full story. The guest said, "So it is. But where are you headed?"

chunks.original_text: 曰：避地太原。 复命酒共饮。 又曰：尝知太原之异人乎？ 靖曰：州将之子，可十八，来#7姓李。 客曰：似则似矣，然须见之。 李郎能致予一见否？ 靖言：余友人刘文靖，与之甚狎，必可致也。 客日望气#8曰：俾吾访之。 遂约期日，相候於汾阳桥。 及期，果至。 靖话於文靖曰：吾有善相者，欲见郎君，请迎之。 文靖素奇其人，方议匡辅，遽致酒迎之。 俱见太宗，不衫不履，褐裘而来#9，神气扬扬，邈与常异。 客见之默#10，居末坐，气丧心死。 饮数杯，招靖谓曰：此真天子也。 靖以告刘，益喜贺。 既出，虹须曰：吾见之，十得八九也，然亦须令道兄见之。 又约靖与妹於京中马行束酒楼下。 既至，登楼，见此须与一道流对饮。 因环坐，为约与道兄同至太原。 道兄与刘文靖对棋，须靖俱会。 文皇亦来，精彩惊人，长揖而坐，神清气爽，满座风生，顾盼伟如也。 道兄一见，惨然下棋子，此局输矣，於此失局，奇哉！ 救无路矣，如复奚言。 罢弈既出，谓虹须曰：此世非公世界也，他方可矣。 勉之，勿以为念。 同入京，虹须命其妇妹与李郎相见，其妇亦天人也。 虹须纱巾褐裘，挟弹而至，相与入中堂，陈乐欢饮。 女乐三十余人，非王侯之家所有，迨若洞天之会。 既而升二十床，以绣杷盖之，去其杷曰：此乃文簿钥匙耳，皆珍宝货泉之数，并以充赠。 吾本欲中华求事，或龙战三五年，以此为经费，今既有主，亦复何为。 太原李氏，真英主也，三五年内，即当太平。 李郎一妹，善辅赞之，非一妹不能赞明主，勉之哉！ 此去十年后，东南数千里外有异，是吾得事之秋也，闻之可潜以酒相贺。 因呼家僮百余人出拜，曰：李郎一妹是尔主也。 言讫，与其妻戎装乘马而去，道兄亦不知所之。 靖得此事，力以助文皇，缔构大业。 贞观中，东南夷奏，有海贼以缕船千艘，兵十余万人於扶余国，杀其主，自立为王。 国内以定静，靖知此须成功，归告其妻，乃沥酒东南而贺焉。 乃知真人之兴，乃天受也，岂庸庸之徒，可以造次思乱者哉！ 东明油客 东明油客，不知名氏，常负担卖油於侧近坊内，亲居观东偏门内数年。 邻里比狎之，谨洁谦慎，未曾见其喜愠。 一旦，邻居有负债者，客知其主，陈牒征讼，所司将欲追捕。 计无所出，议欲窜诸远邑，不然虚系狸牢，郎数口无所赡给，必至俘始，聚族号泣，决别将去。 客问之故，闻之默然良久。 谓之曰：勿用游去，此有计矣。
